Situation1: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story:
It’s a slow afternoon at the register, and I’m scanning groceries for the handful of customers trickling in. My mind keeps drifting to the tax documents I organized last night, stacked neatly at home, ready for filing. I pride myself on being a responsible citizen—paying taxes on time, following the rules, and doing my part for the community. This weekend, there’s a free vaccine clinic at the community center, and I feel a strong pull to volunteer. It’s the kind of thing I believe in, helping out where I can.

But as a cashier, my manager expects me to be here, especially on weekends when the store gets busy. I’m supposed to process every transaction accurately, keep the line moving, and cover shifts when needed. If I ask for time off, I know it’ll put pressure on my coworkers, and I might even risk my hours. The weight of both roles presses on me—my duty to my job and my responsibility as a citizen. I stand at the register, wrestling with the choice, feeling the tension build as I scan another can of soup.
